Students of the University of Edinburgh do not wear any academical costume; but on the 1st of August the medical graduates of the year, attired in black gowns, resembling generally those of Oxford and Cambridge, assemble in one of the largest class-rooms in presence of the principal and professors of the University, the magistrates of the city, and a large concourse of spectators of both sexes. The more important parts of the ceremony, are the administration of a solemn oath to the graduates, and the offering up of prayers by the Principal, but as they are couched in Latin, only a small portion of the audience can intelligently follow them.
